si4.svg svg 11661 ALTIMG YJCAT 116321 116321 S0021-9517(25)00386-0 10.1016/j.jcat.2025.116321 The Author(s) Fig. 1 SEM images of the Ni-foam catalyst before electrolysis: a), b), c) top views at various magnifications, d) cross-view of Ni foam. e) LSV of Ni foam in 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M KOH + 0.05 M HMF. Fig. 2 CVs of Ni-foam catalysts in 0.1 M KOH (pH 12.80 ± 0.10) with c HMF of a) 0 M, b) 0.01 M, c) 0.015 M, d) 0.025 M, e) 0.05 M, f) 0.10 M, and g) 0.25 M. Green and red arrows show the trends in the changes in peak heights: anodic peak (NiOOH formation and HMFOR) and cathodic peak (NiOOH reduction to Ni(OH)2). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3 CVs of Ni-foam electrodes in solutions of differing pH, with (solid curves) or without (dashed curves) 0.05 M HMF. The solutions were as follows: (a–d) 0.1 M (KOH + KClO4), e) 0.15 M KOH, f) 0.5 M KOH, and g) 1.0 M KOH. The scan rate was 0.01 V s−1. pH values are indicated on the graphs. The current densities in (a–e) are multiplied by the factors indicated on the respective graphs. Fig. 4 (a) Operando Raman spectra acquired on Ni-foam catalysts at potentials near the respective anodic peak maxima (1.51–1.58 V) in solutions containing the indicated amounts of HMF. (b) Dependence of integrated intensities (integrated over the range of 320–700 cm−1) on the applied potential. Fig. 5 (a, b) FEs and (c, d) partial charge densities (q) of various HMFOR products formed during 1-h electrolysis in the solutions: (a, c) in 0.1 M KOH (pH = 12.80 ± 0.10) and (b,d) 0.5 M KOH (pH = 13.47 ± 0.10); c HMF = 0.05 M. The solid lines show trends. Respective anodic CV scans (dashed lines) are also shown in the graphs. The respective current transients are shown in Fig. S11. Fig. 6 Near-electrode concentration and pH profiles (the latter shown by coloured bars) approximated based on the data of Fig. 5 for an electrolysis potential of E = 1.64 V vs. RHE, assuming that diffusion (within a fixed boundary layer of 100 µm) limits the achievable current density. Note that while at lower bulk pH, panel (a), electrolysis already results in acidification of the near-surface solution layer, this limitation is lifted when the bulk pH is higher, as in panel (b). See Supporting Information for details of the calculations and Figs. S12 and S13 for approximated profiles at other electrode potentials. Fig. 7 (a–c) FEs and (d–f) partial charge densities (q) of various HMFOR products formed during 1-hour electrolysis in the solutions containing (a, d) 0.01 M HMF, (b, e) 0.05 M HMF, and (c, f) 0.10 M HMF. The solid lines show trends. Error bars represent standard deviations calculated from at least three independent measurements on a fresh Ni-foam catalyst. A set of current transient curves is given in Fig. S14. Department of Chemistry, Biochemistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences University of Bern Freiestrasse 3 Bern 3012 Switzerland Graphical abstract Among biomass-derived compounds, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) has substantial potential as a key platform chemical for producing value-added compounds. The electrochemical oxidation of HMF to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a crucial precursor for bio-based polyethylene furanoate plastics, has garnered particular attention as a green and efficient alternative to the conventional anode reactions of power-to-value electrolyser systems. On NiOOH-based electrocatalysts, studied in this paper, the electrochemical HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR) already becomes at least partially transport-controlled, so that the availability of reactants (both OH– and HMF) at the electrode surface plays a crucial role in determining electrolysis performance. Voltammetric and potentiostatic analyses demonstrate a strong influence of the solution pH on both the reaction rate and the product selectivity, with higher alkalinity favoring selective oxidation to FDCA. On the other hand, extreme high alkalinity accelerates HMF degradation to undesirable byproducts, and complicates the isolation of FDCA. We found that the OH– concentration of the anolyte should outrange that of HMF 2–4 times in order to maximize the FDCA production rate. Furthermore, our results underscore the importance of maintaining sufficient OH− ion availability during prolonged electrolysis to ensure efficient catalyst performance and system stability. These findings provide valuable insights into optimizing HMFOR systems, and may lead to sustainable and economically viable production of FDCA and other bio-derived chemicals. Keywords 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid Solution pH 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural electrooxidation Nickel foam Electrocatalysis Data availability The raw data and unprocessed measurement files on which this article is based have been deposited in the Zenodo repository and are accessible at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14843555. 1 Introduction In the ongoing energy crisis, finding more sustainable alternatives for the production of chemicals has become increasingly important. One promising solution to this challenge is the use of biomass, a renewable, eco-friendly, low-cost, and abundant resource [1]. Among the compounds derived from biomass, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) has great potential to serve as a key intermediate in the transition from biomass resources to valuable platform chemicals [2,3]. Through the oxidation of its functional groups (either alcohol or aldehyde), HMF can be transformed into various value-added compounds, such as 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) (Scheme 1 ). These molecules all have industrial applications. For example, DFF is an important building block in the production of adhesives, antifungal agents, foams, pesticides, and new polymeric materials [4,5]. HMFCA is a versatile chemical used in polyester manufacturing [6] and has also demonstrated antitumor activity [7]. FFCA is highly valuable in the pharmaceutical industry, owing to its use as a drug derivative [5]. Among the potential products of the HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR) and the top ten chemicals identified by the U.S. Department of Energy [8], FDCA is notable for its role as a building block for the synthesis of polyethylene furanoate (PEF) plastics — a superior biobased alternative to the petrochemical-based polyethylene terephthalate [9,10]. Various methods have been used for the oxidation of HMF, including hydrothermal, biocatalytic, photocatalytic, and electrocatalytic approaches [11–14]. Among these, the electrochemical transformation of HMF has attracted substantial attention as a green and sustainable route for FDCA production [15–17]. This method does not require harsh reaction conditions, such as high temperatures and pressures, and it eliminates the requirement for chemical oxidants. Additionally, electrochemical oxidation enables precise control of reaction rates, faradaic efficiencies, and thermodynamic properties through adjustment of key parameters, such as the oxidation potential/current, electrode materials, electrolyte composition, and hydrodynamic conditions [15–21] (Table S1). Furthermore, the HMFOR anode reaction shows considerable potential as an alternative to the sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Therefore, HMFOR can be coupled to a variety of cathode reactions, including hydrogen evolution (HER), CO2 reduction (CO2RR), and nitrate reduction (NO3RR). This approach serves to reduce the gross energy consumption of electrolyser systems. Unlike OER, which consumes substantial energy without producing value-added products, HMF oxidation offers the dual advantage of lower energy requirements, and the generation of high-value chemicals, such as FDCA [22]. This substitution not only enhances the overall efficiency of electrocatalytic systems, but also aligns with sustainable chemical production goals. The net electrode reaction of HMFOR is described by Reaction (R1). When coupled to a hydrogen evolving cathode (Reaction (R2)), the overall cell reaction can be written in the form of Reaction (R3). The net anode reaction (Reaction (R1)) can, however, involve the formation of three intermediates: HMFCA, DFF, and FFCA (Reactions (R4)–(R8), Scheme 1). (R1) Reaction at anode: HMF + 6OH− → FDCA + 4H2O + 6e− (R2) Reaction at cathode: 6H2O + 6e− → 3H2 + 6OH− (R3) Overall reaction: HMF + 2H2O → FDCA + 3H2 (R4) HMF + 2OH− → HMFCA + H2O + 2e− (R5) HMF + 2OH− → DFF + 2H2O + 2e− (R6) HMFCA + 2OH− → FFCA + 2H2O + 2e− (R7) DFF + 2OH− → FFCA + H2O + 2e− (R8) FFCA + 2OH− → HMF + H2O + 2e− Transition metal-based electrocatalysts have frequently been used for the oxidation of aliphatic and aromatic alcohols and aldehydes [23–27]. Specifically, Ni- and Co-based electrocatalysts have been the focus of extensive research for their performance in the electrochemical HMFOR (summarized in Table S1). It has been confirmed that the oxidation of alcohols, aldehydes, and HMFs occurs on Ni anodes via an indirect pathway [20,23,28,29]. This process involves the transition of surface (oxy)-hydroxides from the Ni(II) to the Ni(III/IV) oxidation state (Reaction (R9)), the adsorption of HMF on this over-oxidized surface (Reaction (R10)), and the subsequent formation of an oxidized HMFOR intermediate, which reverts the Ni oxidation state to II (Reaction R11). (R9) Ni(OH)2 + OH– ↔ NiOOH + H2O + e- (R10) HMF ↔ HMFads (R11) HMFads + NiOOH → HMFOR intermediateads + Ni(OH)2 The chemisorbed HMFOR intermediate can be further oxidized to a stable intermediate (HMFCA, DFF, and FFCA) or to the final product (FDCA) through the interaction with NiOOH, which is rapidly regenerated at proper electrolysis potentials from the NiII(OH)2. Here, the notation of NiOOH refers to two possible phases: β-NiOOH (with valency of ∼+2.7 [30,31]) and γ-NiOOH (with valency of ∼+3.6 [30,31]) that can be formed through further partial deprotonation of β-NiOOH during sufficient anodic polarization [29,32–34]. Although NiOOH species are considered as the most active catalytic sites in the indirect oxidation mechanism [17], the involvement of NiIVO2 species into the reaction cannot be excluded [35]. Additionally, direct electrochemical oxidation of HMF or its intermediates can also contribute to the overall HMFOR [20,35], however, according to DFT calculations [35], only at rather moderate pH (≤11). This mechanism involves co-adsorption of OH− on the electrode surface and its transformation to adsorbed OH*, which can act as an oxidizing agent of organic molecules [36]. Regardless of the mechanisms, according to reactions (R1) and (R4)–(R9), the formation of catalytically active NiOOH surface sites and the HMFOR are both pH-dependent. The majority of previous studies on HMF electrooxidation have been conducted in 1 M KOH solutions with low HMF concentrations (10 mM) (Table S1) and an OH − concentration substantially greater than the HMF concentration, i.e., c OH–/c HMF ≥ 10 (Fig. S1). Under such conditions, high Faradaic efficiencies of FDCA formation (FE FDCA > 90 %) are typically achieved. However, using highly alkaline media for the electrolysis has notable disadvantages. Subsequent isolation of FDCA requires lowering the pH to below 2, which necessitates the addition of substantial amounts of sulfuric or hydrochloric acid. Furthermore, HMF stability markedly decreases in the bulk solutions at pH values near 14. Under highly alkaline conditions, HMF undergoes spontaneous polymerization and degradation, thus forming undesirable byproducts, such as humins and maleic acid [37,38], which cannot be converted to FDCA. Moreover, the formation of products with carboxylic groups (FDCA, FFCA, and HMFCA) leads to additional consumption of hydroxyl ions through neutralization reactions (pKa values corresponding to the first and second deprotonation step of FDCA are 2.3 and 3.5, respectively [39]). Such OH– loss cannot be compensated by the transport of OH– ions forming in the cathodic compartment in Reaction (R2). Consequently, OH− loss can lead to a decrease in the rate of the anode process, which can limit the efficiency of the HMFOR. This effect should thus be carefully considered in designing and optimizing electrochemical systems for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Although some aspects such as the effect of HMF concentration on the reaction rate [40] and pH on HMFOR selectivity [32] on Ni-based catalysts have been reported in the literature, our work systematically examines the combined impact of OH− and HMF concentrations on the performance of a synthesized Ni-foam catalyst. Our systematic and methodical experimental approach provides a more profound understanding of system behavior, emphasizing the significance of mass transfer effects in the catalyst performance. Our experiments reveal that both alkalinity and the c OH−/c HMF ratio significantly influence the HMFOR rate and product selectivity. Higher pH values generally promote selective oxidation of HMF to the final FDCA product, while reduced FDCA selectivity at a moderate pH level is attributed to neutralization (in an extreme case, acidification) of the near-surface solution layer. Depending on the c OH−/c HMF ratio, the rate of HMFOR is limited by either OH− availability or HMF mass transport. We identify an optimal OH−/HMF concentration ratio range of 2 to 4 that maximizes the HMFOR rate while minimizing excess alkali use, making the HMF-to-FDCA conversion process economically more viable. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Ni catalyst preparation The Ni foams used as HMFOR catalysts were fabricated through dynamic hydrogen bubble template assisted galvanostatic electrodeposition [41,42]. Before foam deposition, Ni foil substrates (99.7 %, 25 × 8 × 0.25 mm, MaTeck) were thoroughly rinsed with isopropanol (BASF SE, Ludwigshafen, Germany). The Ni substrates were then masked with PTFE tape, leaving an exposed area of 1 cm2 (Fig. S2). The aqueous plating bath consisted of 1.5 M NH4Cl (≥99.5 %, Sigma Aldrich) and 0.12 M NiSO4 (≥98 %, Sigma Aldrich). A potentiostat/galvanostat equipped with a 10 A current booster (Multi Autolab M204, Metrohm, Switzerland) was used in a three-electrode cell configuration, with a double junction Ag/AgCl3M KCl electrode (Metrohm, Switzerland) and Pt foil serving as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively (Fig. S2). Ni-foam deposition was performed at a geometric current density of j geo = −3 A cm−2 for 20 s. After deposition, the Ni foams were thoroughly rinsed and subsequently soaked for 45 min in Milli-Q water (18.2 MΩ cm, TOC ≤ 5 ppb, Millipore) to remove residual electrolyte traces. Finally, the samples were dried under ambient conditions and stored before morphological characterization and electrochemical measurements. 2.2 Nickel-foam characterization by scanning electron microscopy Morphological analysis of the electrodeposited Ni foams before and after electrolysis was performed with a Zeiss Gemini 450 scanning electron microscope. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging was conducted with an InLens SE detector with an accelerating voltage of 5 kV, beam current of 100 pA, and working distance of 5 mm. Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra and elemental mappings were acquired with an X-MaxN 150 detector (Oxford Instruments) and processed in Aztec 5.0 software (Oxford Instruments). For these measurements, the settings were accelerating voltage of 2 kV, beam current of 1 nA, and working distance of 8.5 mm. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Voltammetric measurements and potentiostatic electrolyses were performed in an H-type cell (Fig. S3) with two compartments divided by an anion exchange membrane (Fumasep FAB-PK-130, Fuel Cell Store). A Pt foil and an Ag/AgCl3M KCl electrode (Pine research) served as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively, and the Ni-foam catalyst with a geometric area of 1 cm2 (unless stated otherwise) was applied as the working electrode. Voltammetric measurements were performed in a quiescent solution, whereas the anolyte and catholyte were magnetically stirred during electrolysis. The electrode potentials reported herein are referenced to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Solutions at various pH values were prepared from KOH (reagent grade 90 %, Sigma Aldrich) and Milli-Q water. In the case of low KOH concentration (≤0.04 M), KClO4 (ACS EMSURE, Merck) was added to a total concentration of 0.1 M. The pH of the solutions was controlled through use of a pH meter (Mettler Toledo, FiveEasy Plus), which was calibrated in buffer solutions (Mettler Toledo) of pH 2.00, 4.01, 7.00, 9.21, and 11.00. The compositions of the solutions and their corresponding measured pH values are provided in Table S2. The initial solution volume in the cell was 20 mL for each compartment. HMF (≥99 %, Sigma Aldrich) was added to the working compartment solution to achieve HMF concentrations (c HMF) ranging from 0.01 to 0.25 M. Before measurement, the working compartment solution was purged with Ar gas (99.999 %, Carbagas, Switzerland) for 25 min to remove dissolved oxygen. During electrochemical measurement, automatic iR compensation (85 %) was applied. The ohmic resistance was determined with impedance spectroscopy before each experiment. The presented cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded at a scan rate of 0.01 V s−1 unless otherwise specified. The currents were normalized to the geometric surface area. 2.4 Product identification and quantification Anolyte samples (150 µL) were collected at specific time intervals or after a certain charge had passed during electrolysis, to quantitatively determine the concentrations of HMF and HMFOR products. Each sample was diluted 100-fold with a buffer solution comprising 30 % CH3OH (≥99.8 %, HPLC grade Fisher Chemical) and 70 % 5 mM HCOONH4 (≥99.995 %, Sigma Aldrich). Quantification of the products and HMF was performed with an HPLC system (Shimadzu) equipped with an LC-20AT pump, an SPD-M20A photodiode array detector, a CTO-10Svp column oven, and a ReproSil 100 C-18 column (5 µm, 250 × 4 mm, Dr. Maisch). The flow rate of the mobile phase (30 % CH3OH + 70 % 5 mM HCOONH4) was set at 0.4 mL min−1, and the column temperature was maintained at 45° C. The injection loop volume was 20 µL. The retention times were 3.84, 4.61, 4.78, 8.3, and 9.52 min for FDCA, HMFCA, FFCA, HMF, and DFF, respectively. Detection wavelengths were selected according to the absorbance maxima: 265 nm for FDCA; 250 nm for HMFCA; and 290 nm for FFCA, HMF, and DFF. LabSolutions Lite software was used for data acquisition, analysis, and visualization. The calibration curves (Fig. S4) were obtained with the solutions prepared from HMF (≥99 %, Sigma Aldrich) and the following compounds purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry: HMFCA (>98.0 %), DFF (>98.0 %), FFCA (>98.0 %), and FDCA (>98.0 %). The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of HMFOR products was calculated from Eq. (1) (1) F E i = n i c i V an F Q where ci is the concentration of product i determined by HPLC (in mol L-1), V an is the anolyte volume (in L), ni is the number of transferred electrons (n FDCA = 6, n FFCA = 4, n HMFCA = 2, n DFF = 2; Scheme 1), F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol−1), and Q is the charge passed (in C). FE HMFOR is the sum of the FEi for all oxidation products. 2.5 Operando Raman spectroscopy A LabRam HR800 Raman spectrometer equipped with a confocal microscope (Horiba Jobin-Yvon) and operated by LabSpec 3.0 software (data acquisition and analysis) was used to acquire operando Raman spectroscopy data. All measurements were performed using an He-Ne laser with an excitation wavelength of 633 nm and a laser power of 3 mW. A long working distance objective with 50× magnification and 8 mm focal length was used to focus the laser beam. Before each measurement, the instrument was calibrated with a standard silicon wafer (520.6 cm−1). The Raman spectral range was set from 100 to 1200 cm−1. The operando Raman experiments were performed in a single-compartment cell with a three-electrode arrangement using a µAutolab Type III potentiostat (Methohm, Switzerland) operated by GPES 4.9 software. Au wire and Ag/AgCl3M KCl (BASi RE-6) served as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. After deposition, the Ni-foam was fixed to a glassy carbon electrode (3 mm diameter disc embedded in PTFE) with a silver conductive paste (RS PRO). The electrode potential was typically adjusted in steps of 50 mV. Raman spectrum acquisition was started 60 s after a potential step, to ensure that steady-state conditions were reached. To improve the signal-to-noise ratio, we averaged ten individual Raman spectra, each recorded over 30 s, at each potential. 2.6 Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry The quantitative determination of Ni ions in anolyte and catholyte after the extended electrolysis was performed with a NexION 2000 ICP-MS instrument (Perkin Elmer). For this purpose, aliquots after the electrolysis were diluted 1:10 in water (Milli-Q water). The amount of Ni was determined with two different Ni calibration curves: one prepared with water, and the second prepared with HMF and KOH (50 mM HMF and 0.2 M KOH). In both standards, the detection limit of the instrument was 10 ppb. The raw data and unprocessed measurement files on which this article is based can be downloaded from Zenodo [43]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Voltammetric and spectroscopic characterization of HMFOR on Ni-foam catalysts The dynamic hydrogen bubble template method enables fabrication of porous metal foams with large surface areas. In this process, hydrogen bubbles generated concurrently with Ni deposition act as a template guiding the formation of the foam structure. Fig. 1 a–d shows top-view and cross-sectional SEM images of the as-prepared Ni foam deposited at −3 A cm−2 for 20 s. The obtained Ni catalyst material exhibited a mesoporous structure with pore diameters of 2–15 µm and a cauliflower-like morphology of the pore sidewalls. The foam thickness ranged from 20 to 30 µm. The roughness factor, estimated from double-layer capacitance data, was 59 (Fig. S5). Estimation of the electrochemically active surface under mass-transport limitation conditions, using a viologen redox couple resulted in a roughness factor of only 1.5 (Fig. S6). We note here that under HMFOR conditions, when the diffusion layer thickness is limited only by natural convection (in the approximate range of about 100 µm), the Faradaic surface area is probably even closer to the geometric one. Thus, all currents reported in the paper are normalized to the geometric surface area (1 cm2 unless stated otherwise). Fig. 1e shows the comparison of anodic-direction linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) recorded on a Ni foam in 0.1 M KOH (blank curve) and 0.1 M KOH + 0.05 M HMF. The blank LSV displays an anodic peak at 1.43 V that can be assigned to the oxidation of Ni(OH)2 to NiOOH (R9) [30], whereas at potentials above E > 1.55 V, the increasing current is associated with OER. In the presence of 0.05 M HMF, we observed an anodic wave of HMF oxidation with the onset at 1.30 V. This HMFOR wave coincides with the Ni(II)-to-Ni(III) process (here Ni(III) is simplified notation as it is challenging to differentiate β-NiOOH and γ-NiOOH with intermediate valencies of +2.7 and +3.6 [30,31]), thus confirming the indirect mechanism (R9–R11). Notably, the onset of the HMFOR process occurs at potentials that are around 230 mV lower than those associated with the OER. Furthermore, HMFOR hinders OER, and being itself an OH– consuming process, it shifts the OER wave to more positive potentials by approximately 120 mV, under the studied experimental conditions. The CVs recorded in 0.1 M KOH (pH 12.80 ± 0.10) with varying HMF content (Fig. 2 ) show an increase in the anodic peak height, indicative of NiOOH formation and HMF oxidation (Eqs. (4)–(11)), as the HMF concentration is gradually increased from 0 to 0.05 M (Fig. 2a–e). However, with a further c HMF increase to 0.10 M (Fig. 2f), the peak height remains unchanged, whereas at c HMF = 0.25 M the peak height decreases (green arrow, Fig. 2g). Notably, the height of the cathodic peak at 1.32 V, corresponding to the electroreduction of NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 [30], decreases with increasing c HMF (red arrow). The disappearance of this peak during the cathodic sweep suggests the involvement of all active sites of NiOOH in the HMFOR at higher HMF concentrations, suggesting that under these conditions the formation rate of NiOOH, Reaction (R9) is outranged by the rate at which NiOOH is consumed by HMF in Reaction (R11). Therefore, it seems that at high HMF concentration, at a c OH–/c HMF ratio < 2, the HMFOR rate becomes limited by Reaction R(9). This limitation may result from either an insufficient OH– mass transfer rate with respect to the rate of Reaction(R11), a scenario that is further aggravated by the consumption of OH– in neutralizing acidic products of HMFOR near the electrode surface, or from a competitive adsorption of HMF (reaction R10) leading to the blockage of active catalyst surface sites. The latter could explain the decrease in the anodic peak height, i.e., the decrease in HMFOR rate, in the case of the highest investigated c HMF of 0.25 M (Fig. 2g). The charge obtained from integrating the cathodic peak at 1.32 V can, therefore serve as a qualitative estimate of OH– deficiency (Fig. S7). Fig. 3 presents the CVs of the Ni-foam catalyst in solutions of varying pH, with or without 0.05 M HMF (detailed solution compositions in Table S2). The blank CVs (dashed lines) exhibit characteristic anodic and cathodic peaks corresponding to the Ni(OH)2/NiOOH redox transition. Notably, at lower pH levels (11.49–12.48, Fig. 3a–c), the anodic peaks appear broader than those at higher pH (Fig. 3d–g). This suggests a hindered formation of NiOOH at lower pH. After addition of 0.05 M HMF to the solution with lower pH (Fig. 3a–c), the anodic peak height is even smaller than that in the blank CVs. This finding is attributed to OH− ion deficiency and the blockage of catalyst surface sites by HMF molecules that impedes the efficient formation of catalytically active NiOOH sites for HMFOR. Notably, the c OH–/c HMF ratio was below unity for the measurements shown in Fig. 3a–c. Increasing the pH to above 12.75 (and the c OH–/c HMF to above 2, Fig. 3d–f, green arrow) first leads to a substantial increase in the peak height of HMFOR. However, further increasing the pH from 13.51 to 13.78 (compare Fig. 3f versus 3 g) does not offer any additional benefit, in line with the assumption that at this high abundance of OH–, the minority reactant of HMFOR is already HMF. This conclusion is supported by monitoring the cathodic peak corresponding to the reduction of NiOOH to Ni(OH)2. In the presence of 0.05 M HMF, this peak was absent under substantial OH– deficiency (c OH–/c HMF < 1), thus suggesting that HMFOR was limited by the slow Reaction (R9). The peak appeared and grew when c OH–/c HMF ≥ 2 (red arrow in Fig. 3). This finding indicated alleviation of the limitations associated with OH– deficiency, so that some active NiOOH sites remained available even under HMFOR conditions. Similar voltammetric behavior was observed in solutions with 0.01 M HMF (Fig. S8), but the HMFOR appeared to approach a maximal rate at a lower pH value than that in the case of 0.05 M HMF. Structural changes of the catalyst under operando conditions were studied with Raman spectroscopy at a constant pH of 12.80 ± 0.10 and varying HMF concentrations (0–0.05 M, Fig. 4 and Fig. S9). The spectra were acquired under applied potentials with stepwise increases starting from 0.96 V, at which the catalyst surface was covered with Ni(OH)2, and no HMFOR occurred. As the potential increased, two peaks at 480 cm−1 and 563 cm−1 emerged in the spectra (Fig. S9). These peaks corresponded to Ni–O bending and stretching vibration modes, respectively, in the NiOOH catalyst layer [44,45]. In the absence of HMF, the peaks appeared at 1.36 V, in excellent agreement with previously reported in situ spectroscopic results [33]. This potential corresponded to the onset of the Ni(II)-to-Ni(III) transition, as observed in voltammetric data (Fig. 2a). In the presence of HMF, the peaks appeared at slightly more positive potentials (Fig. S9). A comparison of spectra acquired within the potential range of the anodic CV peak in solutions with varying c HMF revealed that NiOOH peak intensity decreased with increasing c HMF (Fig. 4a). This trend was clearly demonstrated by the dependence of the integrated intensity on the applied potential (Fig. 4b). Notably, a remarkable intensity decrease was observed when the HMF concentration was increased to 0.037 and 0.05 M. Therefore, the spectroscopic data indicated a marked decrease in the abundance of NiOOH species at higher HMF concentrations. This finding supported the indirect mechanism of HMFOR, as described by reactions R9–R11, involving NiOOH as actual catalytically active sites. At higher HMF concentrations, HMFOR was accelerated, as reflected by higher anodic voltammetric peaks (Fig. 2), thereby leading to faster conversion of NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 under anodic polarization via reaction R11. Notably, according to the spectroscopic results (Fig. 4), at 0.05 M HMF and pH = 12.80, i.e., when c OH −/c HMF = 2, the NiOOH availability was already substantially limited. In this regard, the Raman spectroscopy data also aligned with the voltammetric characterization, which indicated a decreasing cathodic peak area attributed to the reverse Ni(III)-to-Ni(II) transition with increasing c HMF, thus suggesting a lower amount of Ni(III) species on the catalyst surface (Fig. 2). Although our results do not exclude a contribution from NiIVO2 species to HMFOR via the indirect mechanism, DFT calculations [35], consistent with our findings, suggest that NiOOH are the most active sites for HMFOR. Furthermore, according to the Pourbaix diagram (Fig. S10), NiO2 phase formation occurs in the potential interval of intensive OER, i.e., at more positive potentials than the anodic peak associated with HMFOR. 3.2 HMFOR under potentiostatic conditions We next examined the effect of pH and c OH–/c HMF ratio on HMFOR with Ni-foam catalysts under potentiostatic conditions. Fig. 5 presents prescreening experimental data for FEi and partial charge densities (qi ) for the formation of different HMFOR products in 1-hour electrolyses, performed at various potentials in 0.1 M (pH = 12.80 ± 0.10) and 0.5 M KOH (pH = 13.47 ± 0.10) solutions containing 0.05 M HMF (exact values in Tables S3 and S4). Data plotted in gray diamonds in Fig. 5 represent the total FE for HMFOR (FE HMFOR) and the total charge densities, q tot. Notably, the latter includes contributions from side reactions, particularly OER. For better correlation of the electrolysis results with voltammetric data, we added the anodic CV scans to the graphs (dashed lines). In higher pH solution (Fig. 5b and d), at the potential interval of the anodic CV peak (from 1.43 to 1.52 V), FE FDCA ranged from 85 % to 94 % and decreased to 55 % after a potential increase to 1.64 V, because of the onset of OER. The sum of FEs for the formation of other less oxidized products (FFCA, HMFCA, and DFF) did not exceed 15 %. Of note, the maximal q FDCA was reached at potentials slightly more positive than the position of the anodic voltammetric peak. In the lower pH solution (Fig. 5a and c), two main products formed within the potential interval of the anodic voltammetric peak, FFCA and FDCA, with maximal FEs of 41 % and 52 %, respectively, whereas the total FE HMFOR was between 86 % and 94 %. Formation of a substantial fraction of partially oxidized products, such as FFCA, occurred due to the insufficient availability of OH– ions in the near-electrode region. Notably, according to Reaction (R8), the presence of OH− was required to achieve further oxidation to FDCA. Consequently, comparison of the results in 0.1 and 0.5 M KOH led us to conclude that higher pH facilitated deeper oxidation of HMF. In 0.1 M KOH solution, FE FDCA as well as FE HMFOR decreased with increasing the electrolysis potential, because of the OER contribution. Furthermore, as in the case of 0.5 M KOH solution, q FDCA also peaked at potentials slightly more positive than the voltammetric peak position and decreased in the potential interval of OER. This behavior can be explained by the strong competition between HMFOR to FDCA and OER, with OH– ions required for both processes. In order to explain the effect of OH– limitation on the product yield of electrolysis, we estimated near-electrode concentration profiles of HMF, FDCA, FFCA, HMFCA and DFF, as well as near-electrode pH profiles by approximative calculations, results of which are shown in Fig. 6 and Figs. S12–S13. These calculations were based on the data of Fig. 5, and the assumption that diffusion to and from the electrode surface was the dominant transport mechanism for all chemical species. We assumed that diffusion takes place within a layer of fixed (approximately 100 µm) thickness, established by natural convection, and apart from the autoprotolysis of water, we did not consider further protolysis phenomena (see the Supporting Information for all details of calculation). Although due to neglecting the afore-mentioned protolysis equilibria, our estimates regarding surface acidification are somewhat exaggerated, our results still illustrate well that the decrease in FDCA selectivity at relatively high applied potentials in the 0.1 M KOH solution can be attributed to the limited abundance of OH– ions in the near-surface solution layer (Figs. 5a and 6a). A lowering of near-electrode pH in this case prevents the formation of products (such as FDCA) that require more OH– ions and promotes that of other, less OH– demanding products (such as FFCA). Acidification is less likely under the same conditions in a more alkaline electrolyte (0.5 M KOH, Figs. 5b and 6b), where a higher bulk OH− concentration helps maintain favorable conditions for FDCA production. Furthermore, we analyzed the dependency of FEi and qi for the formation of HMFOR products on the solution pH at three HMF concentrations: 0.01, 0.05, and 0.10 M (Fig. 7 ). The electrolysis potential for each solution was chosen based on voltammetric data and the prescreening results of electrolyses performed at various potentials (Figs. 2 and 5). Electrolyses were performed at potentials more positive than the anodic voltammetric peaks, to maximize the rate of HMFOR to FDCA while remaining less positive than the onset of intensive OER. The electrolysis potentials, and corresponding FE and q values, are also listed in Tables S5, S6, and S7, whereas the respective current transients are shown in Fig. S14. Table S2 lists all solution compositions, and Table S8 lists the applied potentials at various pH levels. Comparison of the dependencies in Fig. 6 indicated that higher pH facilitated deeper and more selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA. FE FDCA increased with pH and reached approximately 90 % at pH 13.15, 13.44, and 13.62 for the solutions containing 0.01, 0.05, and 0.10 M HMF, respectively (Fig. 7a–c). Therefore, maximizing FE FDCA (within the 1 h timeframe of electrolysis) required sufficient solution alkalinity. Moreover, a higher initial c HMF necessitated a higher pH to achieve maximum FE FDCA. For all studied HMF concentrations, the FEs for the two-electron oxidation products (HMFCA and DFF) were minor, whereas the dependency of FE FFCA and q FFCA on pH generally peaked and then markedly decreased at higher pH, owing to deeper oxidation to FDCA in the presence of OH– excess (Fig. 7). Importantly, the dependency of q FDCA on pH plateaued with increasing pH, and the maximal q FDCA increased proportionally to increasing c HMF (Fig. 7d–f, Tables S5, S6, and S7). To gain deeper insight into the relationship between HMFOR rate on the Ni-foam catalyst and concentrations of HMF and OH–, we plotted the dependencies of the averaged partial current densities for HMF oxidation (j HMFOR = q tot FE HMFOR/t, where t = 3600 s is the duration of electrolysis) against pH for three HMF concentrations (Fig. 8 a, Table S9). The partial current density increased linearly with increasing pH to a threshold, beyond which it plateaued and remained constant. The curves corresponding to different c HMF showed nearly identical slopes, thereby suggesting that, in the respective pH intervals, the rate of HMFOR was mostly dependent on the concentration of OH–. In the absence of a considerable contribution from the side process, i.e., the OER, such behavior is explained by insufficient amounts of OH– anions necessary for the HMFOR (Reaction (R9)). The maximum HMFOR rates (or limiting partial current densities) reached 6.0, 28.3, and 49.9 mA cm−2 at pH 12.48, 12.92, and 13.02 for solutions containing 0.01, 0.05, and 0.10 M HMF, respectively. Because further pH increases did not accelerate HMFOR, the reaction became limited by the mass transport of HMF molecules to the catalyst surface rather than that of OH−. Moreover, the observation that the limiting j HMFOR was proportional to c HMF (Fig. S16) indicated stationary mass transport conditions. The plot in Fig. S16 can be used to predict the maximum HMFOR rate according to the HMF concentration, provided that the process rate does not become limited by OH− availability. The pH values at which the limiting current density was achieved can be considered optimal for maximizing the reaction rate while maintaining an alkalinity of the solution that is not excessive. This balance ensures economic efficiency of FDCA product isolation (by lowering the pH) and minimizes the rate of undesirable chemical degradation of HMF molecules. The ratio c OH–/c HMF (Table S9), when the limiting j HMFOR was reached, ranged from 2 to 4 for our particular electrolysis conditions. However, this ratio may vary according to the Ni-based catalyst structure and mass transport conditions (e.g., solution agitation or solution flow rate in a flow-cell). The determined optimal bulk c OH −/c HMF ratio is significantly lower than the stoichiometric ratio of 6:1 for these reactants in Reaction (R1). This can be attributed to the generally higher diffusion coefficient of OH− ions compared to that of bulky organic molecules, such as HMF. It is worth noting that under transport-limited conditions and provided that the same diffusion layer thickness applies to both reactants, Eq. (2) (2) c O H - c H M F = 6 D H M F D O H - β could describe the optimal ratio of bulk OH− and HMF concentrations. The exponent 0 < β < 1 in Eq. (2) depends on the applied hydrodynamic conditions (e.g., for a rotating disk electrode, β = 2/3). However, Eq. (2) should be regarded as an approximation, as it does not account for potential bulk protonation equilibria or the formation of significant quantities of side products other than FDCA. Fig. 8b shows the dependencies of j HMFOR versus HMF concentration at pH = 12.80. The values are provided in Table S10. j HMFOR also increased linearly with c HMF, reaching 14.9 mA cm−2 at 0.025 M HMF. With further increases in c HMF, the linearity was lost, and the dependence exhibited a maximum at ∼0.10 M HMF. The reaction rate decreased with a further increase in c HMF to 0.25 M. This finding was in excellent agreement with our voltammetric results (Fig. 2), and was attributed to OH– deficiency and diminished availability of NiOOH active sites because of blocking of the catalyst surface with adsorbed HMF molecules at high c HMF. This conclusion is in good agreement with findings from previous reports [16,40]. We additionally observed a good correlation between the data in Fig. 8b, wherein OH– deficiency began to affect the HMFOR rate at c HMF ≥ 0.05 M, and the charge density of the cathodic peak corresponded to NiOOH-to-Ni(OH)2 reduction (Fig. S7), which serves as an indicator of NiOOH active site availability. 3.3 Extended electrolysis A notable effect that has frequently been overlooked in the study of electrooxidation of alcohols and aldehydes is the pH decrease during electrolysis, which is attributable to the neutralization reaction of the formed carboxylic acids. This pH decrease can markedly slow the electrocatalytic oxidation process, because of a shortage in the OH− ions necessary to sustain the initial rate of active NiOOH site formation. This aspect is particularly relevant in cases in which the c OH–/c HMF ratio is not very high, such as within the optimal range of 2–4 (described in the previous section). During extended electrolysis in 0.1 M KOH with 0.05 M HMF (c OH–/c HMF = 2, Fig. S17), we observed a gradual decrease in current density, a finding potentially explained by (i) HMF consumption and/or (ii) a decrease in the catalytic activity of the Ni-foam catalyst due to deficiency in OH– ions. Notably, we detected no significant changes in FEs for the HMFOR products during this electrolysis. The replenishment of HMF in the solution (Fig. S17a) did not lead to recovery of current density; therefore, the process was not limited by HMF availability. In another experiment, after 3 h of electrolysis, we adjusted the pH to its initial value (∼12.75, Fig. S17b). Consequently, the current density increased, although not to its initial level, as the process rate after pH adjustment became limited by the availability of HMF, which had already decreased by that time. In a control experiment in Fig. 9 (Table S13), we replaced the anolyte (0.1 M KOH and 0.05 M HMF) every 3 h and observed full recovery of the anodic current density, whereas FE FDCA and total FE for HMFOR remained nearly unchanged. This experiment demonstrated that the observed decrease in the HMFOR rate was not due to irreversible degradation of the Ni-foam catalyst (Fig. S18) but to the consumption of reactants, particularly OH−. Consequently, pH control and adjustment are imperative during long-term electrolysis, whether in batch reactors or flow cells. Importantly, the decreased pH during electrolysis led to an increase in ohmic resistance, which must crucially be controlled, particularly during potentiostatic electrolysis. Failure to do so can result in substantial undercompensation of the iR drop, thus altering the actual electrode potential. In our potentiostatic experiments, the ohmic drop compensation was adjusted every hour to prevent any substantial deviation in the actual electrode potential. Finally, we conducted extended electrolysis in a solution of 0.2 M KOH + 0.05 M HMF (c OH–/c HMF = 4) until the total charge passed reached the theoretical value for the complete conversion of HMF to FDCA, i.e., 547 C (Fig. 10 ). After the passage of every 150 C charge, the pH was adjusted to its initial value of 13.14 ± 0.05. Under these conditions, the sustained sufficient availability of OH– ions maximized the HMFOR rate (according to the data in Fig. 8a), which was limited only by the mass transport of HMF molecules. Accordingly, the conversion of HMF caused the decrease in the current density (Fig. 10a). However, FE FDCA was ∼81 % and remained unchanged during electrolysis (Fig. 10c). After passage of 150 C, we observed noticeable formation of the four-electron oxidation product FFCA, with FE FFCA = 11 % (Fig. 10b and c). However, during the course of electrolysis, this product was further oxidized, and the final FE FFCA decreased to 1 %, thereby indicating highly selective electrocatalytic conversion of HMF to FDCA. At the end of electrolysis, the FDCA yield was 80 %. Simultaneously, by considering the concentration balance (Fig. 10d), we observed an approximately 15 % loss of HMF during electrolysis. This loss was attributable to the uncontrolled degradation of HMF to side products such as humins and maleic acid [37,38]. SEM and EDX analysis of the Ni-foam catalyst after electrolysis did not reveal any noticeable changes in morphology (Fig. S18–S20). EDX data revealed an increase in the relative O content in the catalyst after electrolysis, which was associated with a larger fraction of Ni in higher oxidation states, e.g., NiOOH, the active catalytic phase (Fig. S19 and S20). No detectable amounts of Ni ions (<10 ppb) were found in the catholyte and anolyte after extended electrolysis, as confirmed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry analysis. These findings indicated that the Ni-foams were stable and minimally affected by corrosion during prolonged HMFOR, thus enhancing the potential of these catalysts for practical applications. 3.4 Discussion of current densities of HMFOR reported in the literature Our results demonstrated that at relatively high c OH–/c HMF ratios (>4), the HMFOR rate was likely to have been limited by the mass transport of HMF molecules to the active catalyst sites. Such conditions apply to most published studies (Table S1 and Fig. S1), in which the ratio was often 100 (1 M KOH and 0.01 M HMF). Nevertheless, many literature reports have indicated j HMFOR significantly exceeding the limiting current densities observed in our study (by as much as an order of magnitude). For instance, in our case, for 0.01 M HMF, the limiting current density was 6.0 mA cm−2 (Figs. 8 and S16). In contrast, j HMFOR values reported at the beginning of potentiostatic electrolysis in solutions with 0.01 M HMF include, e.g., 53 mA cm−2 on Co–Ni/V2O3/NF [46], 20 mA cm−2 on d-NiFe LDHs/CP [47], 127 mA cm−2 on NiFe-LDHs/CP [19], 25 mA cm−2 on CoFe@NiFe [48], and 15 mA cm−2 on NiCoFe-LDHs/CP [49] (where NF indicates Ni-foam, CP indicates carbon fiber paper, and LDHs indicate layered double hydroxides). These are only a few examples among many similar reports. Typically, those studies used commercial 3D Ni foams with pore sizes of hundreds of micrometers or highly porous carbon fiber paper as substrates for catalyst deposition. Such pore sizes exceed the diffusion layer thickness (which is typically below 100 µm [50]) confirming that these catalysts behave as 3D porous structures rather than planar electrode surfaces. Consequently, considering these electrodes as planar and normalizing currents to the 2D geometric area necessarily leads to marked overestimation of current densities. For example, in one prior study [46], the estimated double layer capacitance C dl of Co–Ni/V2O3/NF catalysts was 53.2 mF cm−2, a value 50 times higher than the C dl estimated for our Ni-foam catalyst (Fig. S5), thus indicating a much higher actual surface area involved in the catalytic process in the prior study [46]. Importantly, normalization of the currents by ECSA in the case of mass transport-limited electrocatalytic processes is also not helpful, because under these conditions, the entire surface is not involved in the reaction; consequently, the actual catalytically active surface area is uncertain. The comparison of HMFOR currents across different studies (Table S16). normalized to geometric area and ECSA (estimated from C dl measurements) reveals significant scatter. We attribute this to uncertainties in geometric surface area estimation for 3D porous structures and to the limited reliability of ECSA derived from C dl for normalizing HMFOR currents. The estimation of the active surface area of our Ni-foam catalyst under mass-transport-limited conditions (Fig. S6) yielded a roughness factor of only 1.5, in contrast to the value of 59 obtained from capacitance-based ECSA estimation (Fig. S5). This indicates that mostly the top layer of the porous catalyst structure was involved in the reaction, and that for prolonged electrolyses in unstirred solutions (where the diffusion layer thickness is about 100 µm), our electrodes can be considered quasi-planar. Therefore, although a high surface concentration of active sites is key for efficient catalysis, in the case of mass transport limited reactions, the reported current densities do not necessarily indicate the catalytic activity of a particular material but instead may reflect the degree of surface roughness and the presence of strong enough convection that can penetrate foam pores. We note here that the cell configuration and hydrodynamic conditions may substantially affect how the mass transport of reactants limits the rate of the electrocatalytic process, thus making comparison of reaction rates extremely difficult. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, our study highlights the strong dependence of the HMFOR rate on both pH and HMF concentration when using an Ni-foam catalyst. The HMFOR rate increased exponentially with rising pH until reaching a limit, beyond which the mass transport of HMF molecules became the controlling factor. The optimal c OH–/c HMF ratio, ranging from 2 to 4, was identified to maximize the reaction rate while balancing economic efficiency and minimizing unwanted HMF degradation. Additionally, at relatively high HMF concentrations, the HMFOR rate was hindered by OH− deficiency and surface blockage by adsorbed HMF molecules, thus preventing the efficient formation of NiOOH active catalytic sites. We also demonstrated that the decrease in current density during prolonged electrolysis was due to the depletion of OH− ions rather than irreversible catalyst degradation. Finally, we concluded that achieving an optimal balance of HMF and OH− reactant concentrations, as well as maintaining consistent pH during extended electrolysis, is essential for sustaining the optimal performance of Ni-based catalysts in the selective conversion of HMF to the final FDCA product. coredata.dc:description: Among biomass-derived compounds, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) has substantial potential as a key platform chemical for producing value-added compounds. The electrochemical oxidation of HMF to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a crucial precursor for bio-based polyethylene furanoate plastics, has garnered particular attention as a green and efficient alternative to the conventional anode reactions of power-to-value electrolyser systems. On NiOOH-based electrocatalysts, studied in this paper, the electrochemical HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR) already becomes at least partially transport-controlled, so that the availability of reactants (both OH– and HMF) at the electrode surface plays a crucial role in determining electrolysis performance. Voltammetric and potentiostatic analyses demonstrate a strong influence of the solution pH on both the reaction rate and the product selectivity, with higher alkalinity favoring selective oxidation to FDCA. On the other hand, extreme high alkalinity accelerates HMF degradation to undesirable byproducts, and complicates the isolation of FDCA. We found that the OH– concentration of the anolyte should outrange that of HMF 2–4 times in order to maximize the FDCA production rate. Furthermore, our results underscore the importance of maintaining sufficient OH− ion availability during prolonged electrolysis to ensure efficient catalyst performance and system stability. These findings provide valuable insights into optimizing HMFOR systems, and may lead to sustainable and economically viable production of FDCA and other bio-derived chemicals.
